title: The Nobility of Sävchand and Somchand
subtitle: Section I.5 from JAB Manual 5th edition 2024

storyContent.tagHTML: The Nobility of Sävchand and Somchand

During the 16th century, a wealthy businessman named Sävchand Jeram lived in Vanthali, Gujarat. He owned a large shipping business. Once, a fleet of his 12 ships was returning from a foreign port when it was caught in a storm and stranded on an island for months. With no news, the ships were reported lost.

This was a huge financial blow to Sävchand. His creditors began to panic and demand their money back. One creditor, the prince of Mängrol, insisted on the immediate repayment of 100,000 rupees. Unable to raise the funds, Sävchand's good name was at stake.

In desperation, Sävchand had an idea. He knew of a very noble businessman in Amdäväd named Somchand Amichand, though he had never done business with him. Sävchand wrote a promissory note to the prince, to be paid by Somchand's firm. As he wrote it, he was so overcome with sadness and guilt that his tears fell on the paper, smearing the ink.

The prince presented the note to Somchand's firm. The accountants found no record of Sävchand and were ready to refuse payment. But Somchand, upon seeing the note, noticed the tear stains. He realized that Sävchand must have been in a desperate situation to have written the note, and had placed his trust in him.
Moved by this, Somchand decided to help a fellow noble man in distress. He told his accountant to honor the note and pay the prince the full 100,000 rupees from his own personal account.

<svg class="story-icon" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 20 20" fill="currentColor"><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M15.312 11.424a5.5 5.5 0 01-9.201-4.42 5.5 5.5 0 018.253-1.614l.975-1.298A7 7 0 004.382 9.02a7 7 0 0010.592 5.004l-1.66-1.6z" clip-rule="evenodd" /><path fill-rule="evenodd" d="M12.25 10a2.25 2.25 0 11-4.5 0 2.25 2.25 0 014.5 0zM14.75 10a4.75 4.75 0 11-9.5 0 4.75 4.75 0 019.5 0z" clip-rule="evenodd" /></svg> At the end of the monsoon, Sävchand's ships returned safely! He made a huge fortune from the merchandise. His first priority was to repay Somchand. He went to Amdäväd and offered the full amount plus interest.

However, Somchand refused the money, saying his books showed no debt from Sävchand. Sävchand insisted, but Somchand replied that Sävchand had already paid for the note with his teardrops, which to him were worth far more.

Neither man would accept the money from the other. At last, they agreed to let the Jain community of Amdäväd decide the matter. The community declared that since neither would take the money, it should be used for a noble cause. Both men agreed, added even more money to the sum, and used it to build a magnificent temple complex on Shatrunjay Hill. The complex, completed in 1619 A.D., is still known as Savä-Som Tuk in their honor.

events.title: Lost at Sea
events.description: A fleet of 12 ships belonging to businessman Sävchand Jeram gets stranded during a storm and is reported lost.

events.title: Creditors Panic
events.description: Facing a heavy loss, Sävchand cannot pay his creditors, who start demanding their money back.

events.title: The Prince's Demand
events.description: The prince of Mängrol insists on the immediate repayment of a large deposit of 100,000 rupees.

events.title: A Desperate Note
events.description: Unable to pay, Sävchand writes a promissory note on a stranger, the noble businessman Somchand Amichand, his tears smudging the note.

events.title: Somchand's Nobility
events.description: Somchand receives the note. Though he has no dealings with Sävchand, he sees the tear stains and understands the writer's desperation.

events.title: The Debt is Honored
events.description: Moved by compassion, Somchand honors the note and pays the prince the full amount from his personal account.

events.title: The Ships Return
events.description: After the monsoon, Sävchand's ships return safely, and he makes a huge fortune.

events.title: An Offer of Repayment
events.description: Sävchand goes to Amdäväd to repay Somchand with interest, but Somchand refuses, stating the note was paid for by Sävchand's tears.

events.title: A Dilemma of Nobility
events.description: Neither man will accept the money from the other, so they refer the matter to the Jain community for mediation.

events.title: A Noble Cause
events.description: The community decides the disputed money should be used for a noble cause. Both men agree and add more money to the sum.

events.title: A Temple is Built
events.description: They use the funds to construct a magnificent temple complex on Shatrunjay Hill.

events.title: The Legacy
events.description: The complex is completed in 1619 A.D. and is named Savä-Som Tuk in honor of the two noble men.

charactersData.name: Sävchand Jeram
charactersData.description: A wealthy and honest businessman from Vanthali who faces financial ruin when his ships are thought to be lost at sea.

charactersData.name: Somchand Amichand
charactersData.description: A noble and compassionate businessman from Amdäväd who honors a stranger's debt out of sheer kindness and understanding.

charactersData.name: The Prince of Mängrol
charactersData.description: A creditor of Sävchand who panics and demands immediate repayment, inadvertently setting the story's main events in motion.

charactersData.name: Jain Sangh of Amdäväd
charactersData.description: The Jain community's executive committee that wisely mediates the dispute between the two noble men, leading to the creation of a temple.

quizData.question: What happened to Sävchand Jeram's fleet of 12 ships?
quizData.answer: They were caught in a storm and stranded on an island, believed to be lost.

quizData.question: Which creditor insisted on an immediate repayment of 100,000 rupees?
On whose firm did Sävchand write a desperate promissory note?
What on the promissory note made Somchand realize Sävchand was in great distress?
quizData.answer: The letters were smeared by Sävchand's tears.

quizData.question: Did Somchand have any business dealings with Sävchand before this?
quizData.answer: No, he only knew him by name.

quizData.question: What happened to Sävchand's ships in the end?
quizData.answer: They returned safely at the end of the monsoon season.

quizData.question: When Sävchand tried to repay his debt, what did Somchand say the note had been purchased with?
Who did the two businessmen ask to solve their disagreement over the money?
What was the final decision on how to use the disputed money?
quizData.answer: To build a temple complex on Shatrunjay Hill.

quizData.question: What is the name of the temple complex built by Sävchand and Somchand, completed in 1619 A.D.?

graphicsData.title: The Lost Fleet
graphicsData.description: Businessman Sävchand Jeram is devastated to learn his fleet of 12 ships has been lost at sea, putting him in a dire financial situation.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A worried Sävchand receives a letter telling him his ships are lost at sea.

graphicsData.title: A Desperate Plea
graphicsData.description: To pay a debt, a heartbroken Sävchand writes a promissory note on a stranger, Somchand, his tears falling onto the document.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Sävchand writes a promissory note with tears streaming down his face, smudging the ink.

graphicsData.title: An Act of Nobility
graphicsData.description: Somchand sees the tear stains on the note and understands Sävchand's desperation. He decides to honor the note out of sheer kindness.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Somchand holds the note and looks at the tear stains with a compassionate expression.

graphicsData.title: The Ships Return!
graphicsData.description: At the end of the monsoon, the lost fleet returns safely. Sävchand makes a huge fortune and rushes to repay his debt.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Sävchand stands at the port, overjoyed as his 12 ships sail back safely.

graphicsData.title: A Noble Dilemma
graphicsData.description: Sävchand insists on repaying the debt, but Somchand refuses, saying the debt was paid with teardrops. Neither man will accept the money.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Sävchand offers a bag of money to Somchand, who kindly refuses it.

graphicsData.title: The Savä-Som Tuk
graphicsData.description: The Jain community decides the money should be used for a noble cause. The two men agree and build a great temple complex, completed in 1619 A.D.
graphicsData.imageAlt: The magnificent Savä-Som Tuk temple complex on Shatrunjay Hill.
